questions.question: Question 1: What is the most important mechanism of antiepileptic activity of phenytoin?
questions.explanation:
The most important mechanism of antiepileptic activity of phenytoin is the prolongation of Na+ 
ion channel inactivation. It slows down the rate of recovery of Na+ channels and thus limiting the 
propagation of the action potential. Phenytoin also inhibits voltage-gated Ca2+ channels. This reduces the influx of calcium inside the 
membrane and reduces the inflow of potassium ions during repolarization. At higher or toxic doses, phenytoin facilitates GABA response and inhibits the action of glutamate.

questions.question:
Question 2: A known case of seizure disorder has been on long-term phenytoin therapy. Which of the 
following statements about this drug would be incorrect?

options.b: Metabolism follows only zero order kinetics
options.d: Metabolized extensively by the CYP enzymes in the liver

questions.explanation:
Phenytoin follows first-order kinetics at lower concentrations and as the concentration increases, 
the elimination changes to zero-order kinetics. The rate of elimination of phenytoin varies with 
the serum concentration. As the blood levels rise, the maximal capacity of the liver to metabolize phenytoin is reached. Thus 
even a small increase in the dosage can result in disproportionally high plasma levels. Therefore, 
it requires therapeutic drug monitoring. About 90% of phenytoin is bound to plasma proteins, mainly albumin. Phenytoin is metabolized 
by the CYP enzymes in the liver.

questions.question: Question 3: Which of the following is an incorrect statement regarding fosphenytoin?

options.b: Fosphenytoin displaces phenytoin from protein-binding sites
options.c: Causes hyperphosphatemia in renal failure patients
options.d: ECG monitoring is not required when administering IV

questions.explanation:
Fosphenytoin like phenytoin requires continuous ECG monitoring during IV infusion due to the 
risk of arrhythmias. Fosphenytoin is a water-soluble prodrug of phenytoin. Fosphenytoin is also extensively protein 
bound, mainly albumin. This binding is saturable and fosphenytoin displaces phenytoin from 
protein-binding sites. Hydrolysis of fosphenytoin yields phosphate, which increases the risk of hyperphosphatemia in 
patients with renal failure. It is contraindicated in patients with sinus bradycardia, sino-atrial 
block, second and third-degree A-V block. 278 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 4: A patient presenting to the ER with generalized tonic-clonic seizures is started on phenytoin 
therapy. All of the following adverse effects can be expected in this patient except?
questions.explanation:
Phenytoin causes hypocalcemia and hyperglycemia. It interferes with the metabolism of vitamin D and intestinal calcium absorption and results in 
hypocalcemia. Hyperglycemia and glycosuria can be seen due to the inhibition of insulin 
secretion. Long-term usage of phenytoin can also cause cutaneous pseudolymphoma which is mainly T-cell 
predominant.

questions.question:
Question 5: Which of the following features would you not expect to find in a baby born to a woman on 
phenytoin therapy?
questions.explanation:
The newborn baby is unlikely to have gum hyperplasia. A baby born to a pregnant mother who 
was on phenytoin therapy will be suffering from fetal hydantoin syndrome. Features of fetal hydantoin syndrome are: • Microcephaly • Digital hypoplasia • Cleft lip/ cleft palate Gum hyperplasia is the most common adverse effect of phenytoin in children and young 
adolescents on chronic use.

questions.question:
Question 6: A patient with recent-onset primary generalized epilepsy develops a skin reaction due to 
phenytoin sodium. What is the most appropriate course of action?

options.b: Stop and restart phenytoin sodium after two weeks

questions.explanation:
Hypersensitivity reaction to phenytoin warrants discontinuation of the drug. Switching to sodium 
valproate is the most appropriate course of action for this patient. Sodium valproate is one of the first-line agents indicated for GTCS. Clonazepam and ethosuximide 
are primarily used in absence seizures and are not indicated for GTCS. Clonazepam is indicated as adjunctive therapy in the absence seizures when first-line agents 
(ethosuximide, sodium valproate, lamotrigine) fail to control the seizures adequately.

questions.question:
Question 7: A 51-year-old male complains of severe, sharp, piercing intermittent electrical shock-like pain 
sensation on the left side of his face. The pain was triggered by talking, washing his face, 
eating, and brushing his teeth. Which of the following drugs is most effective to treat this 
patient?
questions.explanation:
The clinical features in this patient are suggestive of a diagnosis of trigeminal neuralgia and 
carbamazepine is the most effective agent for its treatment. If carbamazepine is ineffective, then second-line agents like lamotrigine and phenytoin are used. Sodium valproate although effective for trigeminal neuralgia lacks enough evidence for use. 279 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 8: 270 
Sold by @itachibot Which of the following statements is true about carbamazepine?

options.a: It is indicated in focal seizures with impaired awareness
options.d: It is the drug of choice for status epilepticus

questions.explanation:
Carbamazepine is indicated in focal seizures with impaired awareness. Carbamazepine is an antiepileptic drug that acts by prolonging the inactivated state of the Na+ 
channel similar to phenytoin. It is used in: • Focal seizures with impaired awareness • Focal seizures with intact awareness • Generalized tonic-clonic seizures • Trigeminal and related neuralgias • Manic depressive psychosis. Option B: Carbamazepine is an enzyme inducer. It is a substrate as well as an inducer of CYP3A4 
and CYP2C9. Option C: Carbamazepine causes hyponatremia and not hypernatremia. Other side effects of 
carbamazepine include agranulocytosis or aplastic anemia, hepatotoxicity, water retention and 
hyponatremia (by potentiating ADH action ), and dose-related neurotoxicity. Option D: It is not used in status epilepticus. Lorazepam is the drug of choice for status 
epilepticus.

questions.question: Question 9: If carbamazepine is added to ongoing valproate therapy, what adverse effect is risked?
questions.explanation:
If carbamazepine is added to ongoing valproate therapy, it can result in hepatotoxicity. A combination of valproate and carbamazepine increases hepatotoxicity. Valproic acid may inhibit 
carbamazepine clearance and increase steady-state carbamazepine blood levels.

questions.question:
Question 10: In patients recieving carbamazepine, which of the following idiosyncratic reactions are not 
expected to occur?
questions.explanation:
Peripheral neuropathy is not an idiosyncratic reaction that can occur after carbamazepine use. It 
is a dose-dependent CNS adverse effect. It can be minimized by gradually increasing the dose 
from initiation or reducing the maintenance dose. Idiosyncratic reactions are hypersensitivity reactions like: • Rash • Steven-Johnson syndrome • Eosinophilia • Lymphadenopathy. • Diplopia 280 
Sold by @itachibot Serious hematological toxicity includes aplastic anemia and agranulocytosis.

questions.question:
Question 11: A 70-year-old man is on carbamazepine therapy. Which of the following is expected to occur 
in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Carbamazepine is expected to cause hyponatremia in this patient. Carbamazepine potentiates the action of antidiuretic hormone (ADH). It can result in water 
retention with decreased osmolarity and hyponatremia, especially in elderly patients with cardiac 
disease.

questions.question:
Question 12: 271 
Sold by @itachibot An 8-year-old child diagnosed to have focal seizures was initiated on oxcarbazepine. Which of 
the following would be incorrect regarding the agent being used?

options.b: Enzyme induction potency is less when compared to carbamazepine
options.d: Hyponatremia risk is less when compared to carbamazepine

questions.explanation:
The risk of hyponatremia with oxcarbazepine is higher when compared to carbamazepine. Option A: Oxcarbazepine is a keto analog of carbamazepine. It is a prodrug. The mechanism of 
action of oxcarbazepine is by blocking voltage-gated sodium channels (same as carbamazepine). Option C: Active form is metabolized by glucuronide conjugation. Option B: Oxcarbazepine does not cause auto-induction of metabolizing enzymes. It can induce 
CYP enzymes but less potent when compared to carbamazepine.

questions.question:
Question 13: A neonate diagnosed with rhabdomyosarcoma was started on vincristine, cyclophosphamide, 
and cisplatin. A week after initiation of treatment, the baby had multiple episodes of seizures, 
refractory to diazepam and lidocaine. Workup revealed an elevated ADH level and euvolemic 
hyponatremia. Which of the following drugs can be used to treat this patient?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of refractory seizures induced by hyponatremia caused 
by SIADH (due to anticancer drugs). Phenytoin is used to treat this patient. It is known to 
decrease ADH secretion and stop seizures by correcting severe hyponatremia. Options A and C: Carbamazepine and oxcarbazepine increase the antidiuretic hormone (ADH) 
levels. This leads to increased sensitivity of renal tubules to ADH levels and hyponatremia. 
Carbamazepine cannot be used in SIADH because of its antidiuretic effects. Option D: Phenobarbital does not affect ADH secretion or action and thus will be ineffective in 
stopping the seizures.

questions.question:
Question 14: A 5th-grade student, after receiving multiple complaints from teachers at school for repeated 
episodes of inattention was brought to the OPD. The mother gave a history that her child had 
brief spells of staring associated with lip-smacking movements. Which anti-epileptic drug is 
the most effective for this child?
questions.explanation:
The clinical features are suggestive of absence seizures and ethosuximide is the most effective 
agent for this condition. First-line drugs in: • Typical absence seizures: Ethosuximide (drug of choice), valproate, lamotrigine • Atypical absence seizures: Sodium valproate 281 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 15: A child with absence seizures improves after being treated with ethosuximide. Which of the 
following is the mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.explanation:
The mechanism of action of ethosuximide is by inhibition of T-type Ca2+ channels in thalamic 
neurons at clinically relevant concentrations. It also affects other ion channels affected include voltage-gated sodium channels and potassium 
channels.

questions.question:
Question 16: A 10-year-old child is brought to the OPD with a history of vacant stares lasting for about half 
a minute. The EEG shows a characteristic 3 Hz spike and wave pattern. Which of the 
following drugs can be used for this condition?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of absence seizures. Ethosuximide and valproate are the 
first-line drugs in this condition. Absence seizures are characterized by sudden, brief lapses of consciousness without loss of 
postural control. There is no postictal confusion. The following subtle motor signs may 
accompany the episodes • Rapid blinking of the eyelids • Chewing movements • Small-amplitude clonic movements of the hands Hyperventilation has a tendency to provoke absence seizures. First-line drugs include: • Typical absence seizures: Ethosuximide (drug of choice), valproate, lamotrigine • Atypical absence seizures: Valproate

questions.question: Question 17: Which of the following is not an enzyme inducer?
questions.explanation:
Sodium valproate is not an enzyme inducer. It is metabolized by CYP2C9/19 and is an inhibitor of 
CYP2C9. Phenytoin, phenobarbital, and carbamazepine are inducers of CYP and UGT enzymes.

questions.question: Question 18: Which of the following is not the mechanism of action of sodium valproate?

options.b: Inhibition of T type Ca2+ channels

questions.explanation:
Sodium valproate has no action on the GABA transporter. Mechanism of action of sodium valproate: • Prolongation of sodium channel inactivation • Inhibition of T-type Ca2+ channels • Inhibition of GABA transaminase 282 
Sold by @itachibot • Increases GABA synthesis from glutamic acid.

questions.question: Question 19: Which of the following are not adverse effects of sodium valproate?
questions.explanation: Osteomalacia is not an adverse effect of sodium valproate. The side effects of valproate (mnemonic: VALPROATE) • Vomiting • Alopecia • Liver toxicity • Pancreatitis • Rash • Obesity • Anorexia • Teratogenicity (most common: spina bifida), thrombocytopenia, tremors • Edema

questions.question:
Question 20: Which of the following antiepileptic drugs does not cause fulminant hepatitis as a serious 
complication?
questions.explanation:
Vigabatrin is not associated with fulminant hepatitis. It is largely excreted unchanged in urine 
without undergoing any hepatic metabolism. Sodium valproate, felbamate and phenytoin are associated with fulminant hepatitis.

questions.question:
Question 21: A 23-year-old female patient is admitted to the neurology ward for evaluation of GTCS. She 
reports that she has been on oral contraceptive pills for the past ™ months. Which of the 
following drugs would you prescribe to this patient?
questions.explanation:
Valproate is the drug used for this patient as it does not cause contraceptive failure. Valproate is an enzyme inhibitor and it inhibits the degradation of OCPs. OCPs thus have a longer 
duration of action and less incidence of contraceptive failure with valproate. However, other antiepileptic drugs like carbamazepine, phenytoin, phenobarbital, primidone, 
oxcarbazepine, topiramate are enzyme inducers. They cause increased degradation of OCPs and 
hence lead to contraceptive failure.

questions.question:
Question 22: A 1™-year-old patient was brought to the ER with bilateral jerking movements of arms. EEG 
revealed diffuse, symmetric, bilateral 4-™ Hz polyspike and wave discharges with a 
frontocentral predominance. What is the most appropriate drug for this patient?
questions.explanation:
The clinical features and EEG findings are suggestive of juvenile myoclonic epilepsy. The most 
appropriate drug for management is sodium valproate. 283 
Sold by @itachibot In patients with myoclonic seizures which are refractory to valproate, clonazepam or clobazam 
may be added.

questions.question:
Question 23: 274 
Sold by @itachibot A 55-year-old man visits the neurology OPD with complaints of tremors in both his hands 
which improve on alcohol intake. On examination, there is a significant worsening of tremors 
towards the end of finger-to-nose testing and head-nodding movements. Which antiepileptic 
is approved for use in this condition?
questions.explanation:
The clinical features are suggestive of a diagnosis of essential tremors in this patient. Primidone is 
considered to be the first-line therapy for the same along with propranolol. Bilateral, symmetric tremors involving the hands associated with head nodding (titubation) and 
worsening of tremors towards the end of goal-directed movements such as drinking from a glass 
or finger-to-nose testing is suggestive of essential tremors. Primidone is a barbiturate and functions as a GABA enhancer. It is an enzyme inducer. It is used 
in the treatment of generalized tonic-clonic seizures and partial seizures. It has side effects like sedation, ataxia, and hyperactivity.

questions.question: Question 24: Pseudolymphoma may occur in patients on long-term therapy with:
questions.explanation:
Phenytoin on long-term use can result in pseudolymphoma. This lymphadenopathy can be difficult to distinguish from malignant lymphoma. Although some 
studies suggest a causal relationship between phenytoin use and Hodgkin’s disease, the data are 
far from conclusive. Almost all lesions are benign and termed as pseudolymphoma.

questions.question:
Question 25: What is the most common adverse effect of phenytoin in children and young adolescents on 
chronic use?
questions.explanation:
Gingival hyperplasia occurs in patients on chronic phenytoin therapy. It is the most common 
manifestation in children and young adolescents. Gingival hyperplasia due to phenytoin therapy occurs due to tissue overgrowth secondary to 
altered collagen metabolism. The toothless portion of gums is not involved. It does not warrant 
discontinuation of the drug. It can be minimized by maintaining good oral hygiene.

questions.question:
Question 26: Which of the following is a carbamazepine analogue that has an advantage of once daily 
dosing?
questions.explanation:
Eslicarbazepine acetate is an analog of carbamazepine that has the advantage of once-daily 
dosing. It is a prodrug and is rapidly converted to active licarbazepine. Oxcarbazepine is an analog of carbamazepine that is also converted to licarbazepine. 
Oxcarbazepine does not have the advantage of once-daily dosing like eslicarbazepine acetate. Dacarbazine is not a carbamazepine analog like the other drugs and is a chemotherapy medication 
used in the treatment of melanoma and Hodgkin's lymphoma. 284 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 27: A patient with a history of mitral stenosis presents with the given intractable finding that is 
refractory to conventional therapy. What is the drug of choice?
questions.explanation:
The drug used for refractory intractable rheumatic chorea is sodium valproate, as it doesn't have 
extrapyramidal side effects. Sydenham's chorea is characterized by involuntary, purposeless, jerky movements which mainly 
affect the head and upper limbs. In the tongue, it is visible as the characteristic darting 
movements. Medications used to treat Sydenham chorea are: • Mild cases - Providing a calm environment. • Severe cases: • Dopamine antagonists - haloperidol, pimozide • Antiepileptic medications - sodium valproate, carbamazepine. • Severe, refractory cases - Steroids (thought to be immune-mediated) • IV immunoglobulins, plasmapheresis - limited studies, decreased efficacy (not currently 
recommended)

questions.question:
Question 28: A 10-year-old child is brought to the OPD with a history of vacant stares lasting for about half 
a minute. The EEG shows <3 Hz spike and wave pattern. The first-line drug for the 
management of this condition is:
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario and <3 Hz spike and wave pattern on EEG is suggestive of 
atypical absence seizures. The first-line drug in the treatment of atypical absence seizures is 
sodium valproate. Symmetric 3 Hz spike and wave pattern on EEG is seen in typical absence seizures. First-line 
drugs in its treatment include: • Ethosuximide (drug of choice) • Valproate • Lamotrigine

questions.question:
Question 29: 276 
Sold by @itachibot An 18-year-old girl was brought to the OPD with complaints of excessive growth of hair on 
her face and chest. She is a known case of epilepsy and is on treatment with phenytoin. 
Which of the following drugs would not cause this condition?

options.b: Continue levetriacetam since a 5 year seizure free interval is needed
options.c: Stop levetiracetam and start on a different anti-epileptic
options.d: Discontinue the drug as he is seizure free

questions.explanation:
The given clinical vignette of excessive hair growth secondary to treatment with phenytoin is 
suggestive of hirsutism. Amantadine does not cause hirsutism or hypertrichosis but its 
characteristic side effect is livedo reticularis (bluish discoloration of the skin). Following are the drugs causing hirsutism: • Phenytoin • Anabolic steroids 285 
Sold by @itachibot • Danazol • Metoclopramide • Methyldopa • Phenothiazines • Progestins • Reserpine • Testosterone Following are the drugs causing hypertrichosis: • Cyclosporine • Diazoxide • Hydrocortisone • Minoxidil • Penicillamine • Phenytoin • Psoralens • Streptomycin 286 
Sold by @itachibot Anti-epileptics II
